title: Hit Aussie drama gets a second run
text:
ERIK Thomson is officially Australia’s favourite TV dad with Channel 7 announcing that it has 
commissioned a second series of 800 Words. 
The hit Aussie drama, which features Thomson as bereaved father George Turner, has been a 
ratings monster averaging around 2 million viewers nationally each week since it launched on 
September 15. 
The success of 800 Words is a testament to Thomson’s star power after he anchored former 
Seven hit Packed to the Rafters alongside Rebecca Gibney. Family hit ... Erik Thompson’s 800 Words is returning for a second season, Seven has announced. Picture: Seven Source: Channel 7 
Thomson played dad Dave Rafter for six seasons on Packed to the Rafters and it is easy to 
see 800 Words lasting just as long. 
“I’ve been completely taken aback by the response to the show,” Thomson says. “I knew we had 
made something really special but the way it has been embraced by audiences has been beyond 
my expectations.” 
800 Words follows George, a newspaper columnist, and his teenage children Shay (Melina Vidler) and Arlo (Benson Jack Anthony) as they leave Australia to make a fresh start in the fictional seaside town of Weld, New Zealand, after suffering a family tragedy. Fresh faces ... Melina Vidler and Benson Jack Anthony, pictured with veteran co-star Thomson, had their big breaks in 800 Words Picture: Tim Hunter Source: News Corp Australia 
“For me, what is so special about 800 Words is, while at the core it’s an entertaining drama the 
whole family can watch, it also has an emotional foundation,” Thomson says. 
“There’s an honesty and vulnerability in the characters that has struck a chord with audiences.” 
“What drew me to George Turner and his story is that it tapped into my own intrigue about what it would be like to start over. 
“I’m looking forward to sharing more of George’s story with the audience.” 
Brad Lyons, Seven’s network production direction said the channel prided itself “on being the home of Australian drama”. 
“We’re thrilled that Australian audiences have embraced the Turner family and the people of Weld. It’s further proof good stories well told are key,” he said.
